Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: I notice that some actions are within the same window, like TYPING in Document1.docx. Others cross windows, such as SWITCH from Word to Google Chrome. Also, some actions involve multiple processes, like TYPING in Word and SWITCH between Word and Excel.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So, I'll group these actions into cases. For example, TYPING in Word followed by SWITCHing to Google Chrome would be one case. Similarly, FOCUS on Word followed by SWITCHing to Report.docx is another case.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Next, I'll assign activities. Instead of using raw verbs, I'll create meaningful names like 'Word Typing,' 'Google Chrome Session,' and 'Word Review.'

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I'll also need to include timestamps, case IDs, activity names, and attributes. Since the user wants at least these, I'll include the case ID, activity name, timestamp, and maybe the application and window for context.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: I should ensure that the cases are coherent. For instance, after the Word typing session, the user switches to the Report.docx. Each case should logically follow the previous one, showing a process instance.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: I'll also check for any patterns or repeated actions that can help in forming consistent activity names. For example, save actions (like Save, Delete) follow each other, so they form a case.

Name: Validation - IND
Text: Finally, I'll review the event log to make sure it's easy to analyze with standard process mining tools and that it accurately reflects the user's workflow.
